context: [2] A significant amount of the total DMAPP in leaves is outside of chloroplasts (; ) and, hence, whole-leaf measurements of DMAPP do not give reliable information on the amount of DMAPP that is available to isoprene synthase in the plastid. [3] There is evidence for DOX-d2 contributing to sesquiterpene synthesis  but little evidence that the diphosphates can readily cross the chloroplast envelope. [4] Other cases of cross-talk between the isoprenoid pathways normally involve long time periods . [5] The very large fluxes of carbon needed for isoprene synthesis, as much as 100 times the MEP pathway flux needed to make other isoprenoids in plastids , and the nearly complete elimination of isoprene synthesis in fosmidomycin-fed leaves (; ; ) indicate that DMAPP cannot cross into the chloroplast at rates that are significant for isoprene synthesis in the species tested so far (Phragmites australis, Platanus x acerifolia, Populus nigra, Pureria montana, and Quercus rubra). [6] Thus, we assumed that all DMAPP-d2 was in the chloroplasts. [7] ) measured the 13C-labeled pool of DMAPP in a similar way to distinguish the plastid DMAPP (quickly labeled when plants were fed 13CO2) and cytosolic DMAPP. [1] The estimated Km was 0.97 mm and may have been higher.
